clean_content:
Definition / general

* Choristoma is a tumor-like mass consisting of normal cells in an abnormal location ([J Oral Maxillofac Surg 2012;24:110](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0915699211001440))* Hamartoma is a tumor-like malformation composed of mature normal cells in usual location but as a disorganized mass

Epidemiology

* Most cases occur in adults but may occur at all ages* > 70% of lingual osseous and cartilaginous choristomas occur in females ([Barnes: Surgical Pathology of the Head and Neck, 3rd Edition, 2008 [p822]](http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/0849390230/pathologyoutl-20))

Sites

* 85% of osseous and cartilaginous choristomas occur on tongue (dorsal posterior third near foramen cecum)

Clinical features

* Firm, exophytic, asymptomatic nodule covered by intact oral mucosa* Base may be sessile or pedunculated

Case reports

* Glial choristomas of palate in newborn / one month old ([J Oral Pathol Med 1997;26:147](9083941))* 5 year old boy with buccal osseous choristoma ([Oral Oncology 2005;41:198](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1741940905000415))* 73 year old woman with asymptomatic ventral tongue lesion ([Gerodontology 2009;26:78](18384591))

Clinical images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/oralcavitychoristomascidir01.jpg)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1741940905000415#fig1)

Osseous choristoma

Gross description

* Firm mass covered by oral mucosa, with smooth contour* Usually < 1.0 cm; lesions > 2.0 cm warrant careful microscopic examination ([Barnes: Surgical Pathology of the Head and Neck, 3rd Edition, 2008 [p822]](http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/0849390230/pathologyoutl-20))

Gross images

[Case #142](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/caseofweek/case142.htm)

Various images

  
  
Images hosted on other servers:  

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/oralcavitychoristomascidir02.jpg)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1741940905000415#fig2)

Osseous choristoma

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Oral choristomas can be classified according to types of tissues they constitute ([J Oral Maxillofac Surg 2012;24:110](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0915699211001440)):
  1. Salivary gland choristoma
     1. Central* Gingival* Both have ectopic salivary gland tissue appearing as a raised tumor-like mass; must not have any connection with normal minor or major salivary glands* Cartilagenous choristoma: composed of mature hyaline cartilage in fibrous tissue that resembles perichondrium; usually multilobulated; chondrocytes vary from small to large but lack atypia* Osseous choristoma: composed of dense mature bone; osteocytes are compact and unremarkable; no prominent osteoblastic rimming; occasionally bone and cartilage are present in same lesion* Lingual thyroid choristoma* Lingual sebaceous choristoma* Glial choristoma* Gastric / respiratory mucosal choristoma
                 1. Solid* Cystic

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/oralcavityosseouschoristomaijpm01.jpg)](https://www.ijpmonline.org/viewimage.asp?img=IndianJPatholMicrobiol_2009_52_1_86_44975_u1.jpg)
 
[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/oralcavityosseouschoristomaijpm02.jpg)](https://www.ijpmonline.org/viewimage.asp?img=IndianJPatholMicrobiol_2009_52_1_86_44975_u2.jpg)

Base of tongue

Differential diagnosis

* **Cartilaginous metaplasia**:
  + Usually occurs in soft tissue beneath ill fitting dentures, has diffuse deposits of calcium, scattered cartilaginous cells arranged in various stages of maturation in single or clustered foci* [Pleomorphic adenoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/salivaryglandspleomorphicadenoma.html):
    + May have osteocartilaginous foci* **Salivary gland tissue**:
      + Choristomas lack salivary gland ductal or myoepithelial components
